column1: Mitchell has a humid continental climate

column1: Mitchell is home of the Corn Palace. The Corn Palace is decorated with several colors of dried corn and grains
column2: creating murals. The theme of the external murals is changed yearly at fall harvest; internal murals are changed approximately every ten years. The building itself is used for several purposes including a basketball arena

column1: Mitchell is also the home of the Dakota Discovery Museum
column2: whose mission is to present and preserve the history of the prairie and the people who settled it.  The museum covers the time period from 1600
column3: when the Native Americans were still largely undiscovered
column5: the end of the Great Depression.  The museum holds one of the most complete and pristine collections of American Indian quill and bead-works.  The Dakota Discovery Museum also features artists such as Harvey Dunn
column7: Charles Hargens and Oscar Howe.  In the village area behind the main building are four authentic historical buildings
column8: including an 1885 one-room school house and the fully furnished 1886 Victorian-Italianate home of the co-founder of the Corn Palace
column9: Louis Beckwith.  Two new features of the museum are Discovery Land
column10: a hands-on activity area for children ages five to ten
column12: which brings indigenous plants to the gardens surrounding the museum and historical buildings.

column2: an archaeological site where scientists are excavating a Native American village
column3: is another attraction in the city. The site
column5: is believed to have been occupied by ancestors of the present-day Mandan
column6: who now reside in North Dakota.  The excavation is unique in that it is enclosed by an Archeodome
column7: a climate-controlled building built over the site
column8: which allows scientists to continue their excavation work year-round.
